skill.name: mcp-builder
skill.description: Guide for creating high-quality MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers that enable LLMs to interact with external services through well-designed tools. Use when building MCP servers to integrate external APIs or services, whether in Python (FastMCP) or Node/TypeScript (MCP SDK).

security_audit.summary: Official skill from Anthropic and treated as pre-reviewed. No detailed security scan was required for this audit. No risks identified in this minimal review.

content.user_title: Build MCP servers with clear tool design
content.value_statement: You need reliable MCP servers that agents can use without confusion. This guide provides tested patterns, templates, and evaluation steps for Python and TypeScript.
actual_capabilities: Provides a phased workflow for researching, designing, implementing, and testing MCP servers
Includes TypeScript SDK guidance with registerTool patterns and Zod schemas
Includes Python FastMCP guidance with Pydantic models and tool decorators
Supplies an evaluation harness script to run XML question sets against MCP servers
Defines MCP best practices for naming, pagination, transport, and error handling
limitations: Does not provide a ready-made server for any specific third-party API
Requires external SDK documentation fetched from the web for full reference
Evaluation script needs an Anthropic API key and a running MCP server
Focuses on guidance and examples, not automated code generation

use_cases.title: Design server tools
use_cases.description: Plan tool names, schemas, and error handling before building a new MCP server.

use_cases.title: Implement in Python or TS
use_cases.description: Follow the language guide to implement FastMCP or TypeScript MCP servers.

use_cases.title: Create evaluations
use_cases.description: Generate stable XML questions and run the evaluation harness to score tools.

prompt_templates.title: Basic plan
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a four phase plan to build an MCP server for a calendar API. Include tool naming and pagination decisions.

prompt_templates.title: Tool schema draft
prompt_templates.prompt: Draft a TypeScript registerTool spec for a task search tool with Zod input schema and response_format support.

prompt_templates.title: Evaluation set
prompt_templates.prompt: Write 10 read only evaluation questions for a CRM MCP server. Ensure each answer is a single stable value.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my MCP server design for naming, annotations, error messages, and pagination. Provide a concise checklist of gaps.

output_examples.input: Create a checklist for a TypeScript MCP server before release.
output: Confirm registerTool usage with Zod schemas and strict validation
Verify tool annotations and clear descriptions for each tool
Check pagination metadata and response formatting rules
Run build and a sample evaluation task set

best_practices: Use clear tool names with service prefixes and action verbs
Support both markdown and JSON response formats
Implement pagination with limit, offset, and has_more fields
anti_patterns: Using deprecated SDK APIs instead of registerTool
Returning oversized responses without truncation guidance
Writing tools that mix unrelated actions in one call

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. It provides MCP server guidance that works across those clients.

faq.question: What are the main limits of this skill?
faq.answer: It is guidance and examples only. It does not ship a working API server.

faq.question: How do I integrate it into my build process?
faq.answer: Follow the language guides and run the evaluation script with your server.

faq.question: Does it store or send my data?
faq.answer: No. It is documentation and local scripts only.

faq.question: What if the evaluation script fails to connect?
faq.answer: Check transport type, server URL or command, and required headers.

faq.question: How does it compare to generic MCP guides?
faq.answer: It includes detailed tool patterns, evaluation steps, and best practices.
